CNCSP 25.title: The Role of Research in Society
CNCSP 25.description: The course aims to help students understand the intersection between research and society by exploring the different types of research approaches and their impact on policies and programs. Students completing this course will have a basic foundation for evaluating the quality of research, and its use in policy and program design and evaluation.

CNCSP 26.title: Equity and Diversity in School and Community Settings
CNCSP 26.description: Focuses on understanding historical and contemporary patterns in the relationship between human service institutions (e.g., schools, health care, community services, and support) and various diverse groups in the United States, and ways to include culturally-sustaining and inclusive practices.

CNCSP 99.title: Independent Studies
CNCSP 99.description: Study of special problems in various fields of Applied Psychology.

CNCSP 101.title: Introduction to Helping Skills: Theory, Research and Practice
CNCSP 101.description: Introduces students to theory and practice of psychotherapy and other  helping relationships. Students learn about counseling, assessment,  ethics, and helping skills. Students gain experience by serving as   practice counseling clients or by volunteering in a relevant service   setting.

CNCSP 102.title: Research in Applied Psychology
CNCSP 102.description: Introduces students to research in applied psychology, including approaches to survey, experimental, and qualitative investigation. Students will be exposed to current research in applied psychology through journal articles, presentations, and participation in research studies.

CNCSP 104.title: Innovations in Health Equity Research: Participatory Action with Communities
CNCSP 104.description: The seminar introduces students to community-based participatory research (CBPR) methods focused on health/mental health disparities within the broader context of social inequalities and underrepresented populations living in California.

CNCSP 110.title: Introduction to Educational and Vocational Guidance
CNCSP 110.description: An overview of the theories and concepts involved in career decision making. Develop working knowledge of career information and field survey techniques for understanding the job market in relation to economic trends.

CNCSP 111.title: Identity and Pluralism
CNCSP 111.comments: Preference given to students in the Education and Applied Psychology   Minor.
CNCSP 111.description: Course addresses topics such as racism, heterosexism, ageism, and gender inequality.  Students will not only learn about the current ideas in   these areas, but also engage in personal exploration pertaining to these and related topics.

CNCSP 112.description: Positive Psychology examines how people live life well.  It looks at   those factors associated with living a happy, meaningful life. Course  examines key concepts that include hope, gratitude, grit and optimism to promote well-being and authentic happiness.

CNCSP 113.title: The Achievement Gap: Societal and Educational Issues
CNCSP 113.description: Course examines various educational and societal contributors to the   achievement gap and explores ways these issues might be addressed.   Issues related to assessment, literacy, motivation, and learning will be the primary focus.

CNCSP 114.title: Psychology of Gender
CNCSP 114.description: Provides an overview of psychological theory and research related to   gender issues. Topics include bias in psychology, gender socialization,  communication styles, lifespan development, ethnicity, education,    careers, relationships, violence and victimization, health and mental  health.

CNCSP 115.title: College Student Peer-Helping and Leadership
CNCSP 115.description: Introduces students to theory, research, and practice of college student peer-helping and leadership, including college student development,  helping skills, group facilitation, diversity, challenges faced by   college students, and community-building.

CNCSP 117.title: School-Based Mental Health
CNCSP 117.description: This course introduces students to school-based efforts to promote mental health and wellness. We examine strategies implemented in schools directed toward the prevention and intervention of behavioral, emotional, and other mental health problems.

CNCSP 118.title: The Psychology of Flourishing
CNCSP 118.description: The purpose of this experiential seminar is to explore and critique the empirical literature on the psychology of flourishing including the personal, interpersonal, and contextual factors that impede and/or promote this state of well-being.

CNCSP 190.title: Introduction to Autism
CNCSP 190.description: Overview of diagnostic, clinical, and educational approaches used for autism. Intervention procedures in clinical, school, and family settings are discussed in relation to language development, social development, and self-stimulatory behavior, self-injury, and pivotal behaviors related to a favorable prognosis.

CNCSP 199.title: Independent Studies
CNCSP 199.description: Study of special problems in various fields of Applied Psychology.

CNCSP 200.title: Research Design and Methods in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 200.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Education 277B.
CNCSP 200.description: Examination of both clinical and statistical approaches to professional  psychology research. Special attention devoted to conceptualizing and  developing research proposals in the area of professional psychology.

CNCSP 201.title: Research Foundations in School Psychology
CNCSP 201.description: This course introduces research methods and statistical analytic approaches that are most useful for school psychologists. Includes descriptive and inferential statistics; test development / psychometrics; experimental, descriptive, and mixed method designs, single-subject designs; program evaluation; and research.

CNCSP 202.title: Qualitative Research Methods in Applied Psychology
CNCSP 202.description: Introduces graduate students in Counseling, Clinical and School Psychology to qualitative theory and philosophical paradigms, as well as to the most commonly used qualitative methods in applied psychology. Qualitative data management software will also be introduced.

CNCSP 204.title: Innovations in Health Equity Research: Community Based Participatory Action Research and Communities
CNCSP 204.description: Introduces graduate students to CBPR theory and philosophical paradigms, as well as to the commonly used CBPR methods in applied health/mental health research through social justice-based methodology that engages community members in the work as equal partners.

CNCSP 209A.title: Research Practicum I
CNCSP 209A.description: Student works with research team to develop or conduct an on-going   research study. Focus on learning the process of planning and carrying out a research program.

CNCSP 210.title: Neuroanatomy and Psychopharmacology
CNCSP 210.description: Introduces students to basic neuroanatomy and neurological functioning   across lifespan. Relationship of neurological structure to psychiatric   disorder is highlighted. Also serves to give students a background in  clinical psychopharmacology. Biomedical treatments for child and adult   disorders are explored.

CNCSP 212.title: Cognitive Development in Autism and Other Severe Disabilities
CNCSP 212.description: An overview of diagnostic and treatment methods in the area of autism and  other severe disabilities. Discussion topics include research on language, social behavior, self-injury, self-stimulation, research on physiological, educational, and behavioral interventions used in clinical, school and   family settings.

CNCSP 214.title: Social Bases of Behavior for Applied Psychology
CNCSP 214.description: Course introduces the social bases of behavior. Students have the    opportunity to read classics in the field of social psychology, social   influence, and social cognition. Application to clinical work, group   psychotherapy, and interpersonal behavior are highlighted.

CNCSP 215.title: Cognitive and Affective Bases of Behavior
CNCSP 215.description: This seminar emphasizes cognitive and affective bases of human behavior, including knowledge of (a) cognition, (b) theories and empirical bases of learning, memory, motivation, affect, emotion, executive function,  and information processing and (c) factors that influence cognitive  performance and/or emotional experience and their interaction.

CNCSP 216.title: Historical and Philosophical Foundations of Professional Psychology
CNCSP 216.description: Facilitates a selective and critical analysis of the         historical/philosophical foundations of western psychology. To this end, attention is directed to those individuals, ideas and events that have   shaped the history of psychology.

CNCSP 220.title: Human Development
CNCSP 220.description: Theory and research regarding processes/dimensions of human development  (e.g., cognitive, social, emotional, individual processes, interpersonal processes, the self and gender roles). Special attention is given to   social relationships and their developmental significance.

CNCSP 222A.title: Descriptive Diagnosis
CNCSP 222A.description: Course is the first in the assessment sequence and provides an     introduction to descriptive diagnosis via the DSM-IV. It is designed as an introduction to courses in psychopathology, cognitive assessment, and  personality assessment.

CNCSP 223B.title: Developmental Psychopathology
CNCSP 223B.description: An introduction to the domain of developmental psychopathology, the study  of psychological problems in the context of human development. Emphasis on the developmental origins and developmental consequences of social,    emotional, and behavioral disturbances during childhood and adolescence.

CNCSP 224A.title: Professional Organizations
CNCSP 224A.description: Explores issues related to professional training and practice in     scientific-professional psychology. Topics include internship, graduate  training models, history of scientific-professional psychology,    professional organizations, credentialing, licensure and employment    settings.

CNCSP 225.title: Ethical Standards in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 225.description: Course examines scientific and professional ethics in applied psychology.  In addition to reviewing existing standards, the course focuses on a range of ethical and legal issues such as confidentiality, dual relationships, and client rights.

CNCSP 226.title: Understanding Diversity, Advancing Equity and Social Justice
CNCSP 226.description: This course focuses on understanding historical and contemporary patterns in the relationship between human service institutions (e.g., schools) and various diverse groups in the United States, and ways to advance equity and social justice practices.

CNCSP 227.title: Social and Cultural Bases of Diversity
CNCSP 227.description: Acquaints students with the social and cultural bases of diversity and to  enhance multicultural competence. Designed to enhance awareness,     knowledge, and skills for providing culturally relevant, sensitive, and  effective services to diverse populations.

CNCSP 250.title: Cognitive Assessment in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 250.comments: There is a course materials fee for assessment workbooks, $25 per student.
CNCSP 250.description: Provides in-depth coverage of the Wechsler series, the Stanford Binet (4th ed) and other major tests of cognitive ability. A general approach to test administration and interpretation is stressed. General issues in test bias are used to guide class discussion.

CNCSP 251.title: Personality and Emotional Assessment
CNCSP 251.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 251.comments: There is a course materials fee for assessment workbooks, $25 per student.
CNCSP 251.description: Introduces students to the major tools and techniques for conducting comprehensive psychological assessments, appropriate for adult, children, and adolescents. Self-report, projective techniques, and behavior ratings are discussed in-depth.

CNCSP 252.title: Advanced Personality Assessment
CNCSP 252.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 252.description: Students learn to score and interpret the Rorschach Inkblot Test at a level required for independent practice. Also covered are advanced techniques for integrating assessment results and using assessment in psychological treatment planning.

CNCSP 255.title: Neuropsychological Assessment
CNCSP 255.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 255.comments: There is a course materials fee for assessment workbooks, $25 per student.
CNCSP 255.description: Students are exposed to the methods and techniques of applied neuropsychology. Course material covers the administration, scoring, and interpretation of measures of memory, executive functioning, speech and language, and motor processing.

CNCSP 256.title: Behavioral Assessment and Intervention for Children and Adolescents
CNCSP 256.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 256.description: History and philosophy of behavior management approaches, behavioral assessment procedures, treatment delivery paradigms, parent-training, nonaversive/aversive issues, generalization and maintenance of treatment gains, causes, evaluation of behavior changes, medicine, self-management.

CNCSP 257B.title: Psychoeducational Assessment and Intervention
CNCSP 257B.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 257B.comments: There is a course materials fee for assessment workbooks, $25 per student.
CNCSP 257B.description: Method of psychoeducational assessment and evaluation for identification, intervention, progress monitoring, and educational decision-making planning, and review of progress of children in the public schools. Consideration of screening and diagnostic instruments and procedures, plus instruments and materials to assure nondiscriminatory assessment.

CNCSP 260A.title: Theories of Counseling and Psychotherapy
CNCSP 260A.description: Develops an understanding and appreciation of the major philosophies and theories in the field of professional psychology. Special attention    directed toward examination of applicability of theories and inherent  techniques to racial/ethnic minority populations.

CNCSP 260B.title: Basic Practicum I
CNCSP 260B.prereq_description: Admission to M.Ed. or Ph.D. in Counseling/Clinical/School Psychology
CNCSP 260B.description: Initial practicum in counseling focuses on building a counseling     relationship. Students learn theory and practice of basic counseling   skills, the working alliance, and multicultural adaptations.

CNCSP 260C.title: Basic Practicum II
CNCSP 260C.description: Focuses on case conceptualization of clients. Students learn to plan   treatment on the basis of initial interview, a formal intake, history and  present symptoms and client goals.

CNCSP 261.title: Counseling Psychology Seminar
CNCSP 261.description: Course covers key aspects of counseling psychology, such as social   justice, positive psychology, and prevention. The course covers    professional and research literature and skill development to prepare  students to implement these approaches in research and practice.

CNCSP 261A.title: Theories of Career Development
CNCSP 261A.description: Focuses on theories of career development, current trends in research and  the input of technological and social changes in the society on the role of work in life span development.

CNCSP 261B.title: Theory and Research of Group Counseling
CNCSP 261B.description: Reviews current theory, research, and practices related to group     counseling. Special attention is given to comparisons of theoretical   approaches and accompanying research strategies used in assessing the  effectiveness of group counseling modalities.

CNCSP 262B.title: School-Based Mental Health Services
CNCSP 262B.description: Group, individual and system strategies for evidence-based prevention and  intervention with children and adolescents in the schools and communities. Problems and processes involved in the implementation of these strategies  and programs are also explored.

CNCSP 262C.title: Counseling Children and Families
CNCSP 262C.description: Covers counseling and psychotherapy for children,  adolescents, and    families. CBT, play therapy, and family systems therapies are examined.

CNCSP 262D.title: School Safety, Violence, and Crisis Response
CNCSP 262D.description: Seminar offers foundation knowledge regarding school safety, school    violence, and school crisis response to contribute to scholarship and  practice emphasizing understanding and implementation of prevention and  intervention programs that promote the mental health and physical    well-being of students.

CNCSP 263A.title: Advanced Psychotherapy Techniques
CNCSP 263A.description: Exploration of techniques of major psychotherapy theories, evidence based  practices, and application to diverse populations.

CNCSP 264A.title: Supervision and Consultation in Applied Psychology
CNCSP 264A.description: An overview of theory and research on (a) the process and outcomes of  supervision of professional psychologists and (b) consultation models in applied psychology.

CNCSP 268A.title: Gender Issues in Counseling
CNCSP 268A.description: Familiarizes students with theoretical approaches to working with gender in counseling, course reviews scholarship related to pscyho-social   concerns that disproportionately affect women and men, and demonstrates  clinical approaches to working with gender issues in therapy.

CNCSP 268B.title: Counseling LGBT Clients
CNCSP 268B.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; must be enrolled in Counseling/Clinical/School
CNCSP 268B.description: Course equips students with the knowledge, attitude awareness, and skills  necessary to work effectively with lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender clients on a variety of issues.

CNCSP 268C.title: Racial/Ethnic Minority Counseling Interventions
CNCSP 268C.description: Critical examination of prevailing counseling intervention strategies with racial/ethnic minorities. Focus on identification of ways to improve the quality and utility of the interventions.

CNCSP 270.title: Advanced Fieldwork: General
CNCSP 270.description: Course involves supervised work with adults, children, adolescents, and  families in the Hosford Clinic. Supervised work includes intakes,    assessment, counseling & psychotherapy.  Related readings, case notes,   written case conceptualizations, and other written assignments and clinic  responsibilities are required.

CNCSP 271A.title: Hosford Clinic Practicum
CNCSP 271A.prereq_description: Limited to CCSP students only; consent of instructor.
CNCSP 271A.description: CCSP students see community clients on a periodic basis for psychological services in the CCSP Hosford Counseling and Psychological Services Clinic. Students are supervised by clinic supervisors and professionals from the field.

CNCSP 271B.title: Advanced Practicum: Mind and Behavioral Assessment Clinic
CNCSP 271B.prereq_description: CNCSP 250 or consent of instructor; limited to CCSP students only.
CNCSP 271B.description: CCSP students see 1-4 community clients on a weekly basis for psychotherapy in the Gevirtz Graduate School of Education Hosford Counseling Clinic. Students are supervised by clinic supervisors and professionals from the field.

CNCSP 272.title: Advanced Fieldwork: Counseling Psychology
CNCSP 272.prereq_description: Three quarters of CNCSP 270; consent of instructor.
CNCSP 272.description: Advanced supervised fieldwork in an approved counseling setting under the  supervision of a licensed psychologist. A minimum of two full days each  week in an approved setting is required.

CNCSP 273.title: Advanced Fieldwork: Clinical Psychology
CNCSP 273.description: Advanced supervised fieldwork in an approved clinical setting under the  supervision of a licensed psychologist. A minimum of two full days each  week in an approved setting is required.

CNCSP 274A.title: Contemporary Issues in Student Services: School Psychology First Year  Induction
CNCSP 274A.comments: Course is for first year school psychology students.
CNCSP 274A.description: University-based supervision, school placements. A seminar course    discussing contemporary issues in student services; includes practica.

CNCSP 274B.title: Contemporary Issues in Special Education Process: School Psychology First  Year Induction
CNCSP 274B.comments: Course is for first year school psychology students.
CNCSP 274B.description: University-based supervision and school placements. A seminar course   discussing contemporary issues in special education process; including   practica.

CNCSP 274C.title: School Discipline and Alternative Schooling: Psychology First Year   Induction
CNCSP 274C.comments: Course is for first year school psychology students.
CNCSP 274C.description: University-based supervision, school placements. A seminar course    discussing school discipline and alternative schooling; includes practica.

CNCSP 274D.title: Assessment and Data-Based Decision-Making in the Schools: School Psychology Practicum
CNCSP 274D.prereq_description: Enrollment in the school psychology credential program; CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 274D.description: Introduction to the school's instructional setting. Core instructional features and pro-social prevention efforts are operationalized and examined in schools. Students learn to identify system-level intervention targets.

CNCSP 274E.title: Ethics, Diversity, and Specialized Assessment and Intervention: School Psychology Practicum
CNCSP 274E.prereq_description: Enrollment in school psychology credential program; CNCSP 250 with a minimum grade of B.
CNCSP 274E.description: Participation in didactic instruction and practical experiences in working with culturally and linguistically diverse children. Examination of issues in  working with children of different ages, in different settings, risk factors and disabilities. Specialized assessment models using  single-subject design assessing intervention effectiveness.

CNCSP 274F.title: The School Psychologist as the Intervention Consultant: School Psychology  Practicum
CNCSP 274F.prereq_description: Enrollment in the school psychology credential program; consent of
CNCSP 274F.description: Planning and implementing interventions in the school.  Students monitor progress, provide feedback, engage in data-based decision-making in    collaboration with teachers, parents and system administrators to    facilitate improved child outcomes.

CNCSP 274G.title: Advanced Fieldwork: School-based Mental Health Theories and Interventions
CNCSP 274G.description: Course involves supervised work in local schools and training related to school-based mental health theories and evidence-based interventions.  Supervised work includes assessment, consultation, and therapy.  Related readings, case notes, written case conceptualizations, case presentations, and other assignments are required.

CNCSP 274H.title: Advanced Fieldwork: Advancing Science and Practice to Support Diverse Students
CNCSP 274H.description: Course involves supervised work in local schools and training on bridging the science-practice gap.  Designed to enhance awareness and skills for providing culturally relevant, sensitive, effective, and responsive services to diverse populations.  Supervised work includes assessment, consultation, and school-based therapy.

CNCSP 274I.title: Advanced Fieldwork: Fundamentals of Supervision
CNCSP 274I.description: Course involves supervised work in local schools and content related to supervision.  Theory and research on supervision of school psychologists with a focus on preparing students for their role as a supervisor.  Supervised work includes assessment, consultation, and school-based therapy.

CNCSP 275.title: Internship in School Psychology
CNCSP 275.description: Advanced internship in school psychology in a setting approved by faculty. Twenty to forty hours weekly of fieldwork under the supervision of a   credentialed school psychologist are required.

CNCSP 276A.title: Advanced Fieldwork: Clinical Supervision
CNCSP 276A.prereq_description: At least 6 quarters of practicum experience in a clinical, counseling, or  school setting; consent of instructor.
CNCSP 276A.description: Supervised fieldwork experience in the supervision of beginning    therapists. A minimum of three hours/week of classroom experience and  three hours/week of supervision in individual group sessions are required.

CNCSP 277.title: Autism Center Clinical Practicum
CNCSP 277.description: CNCSP 277 is a clinical practicum course that gives graduate students the opportunity to gain supervised therapy/intervention and/or assessment experience with children and adults who have autism and related conditions.  All practicum experiences are supervised by a licensed psychologist.

CNCSP 279A.title: Internship in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 279A.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and advancement to candidacy.
CNCSP 279A.comments: A three-quarter in progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of CNCSP 279C. May take for 12 units/quarter for  one year, or 6 units/quarter for two years. Total of 36 units required.
CNCSP 279A.description: Advanced fieldwork internship in an approved setting. Twenty to fourty   hours weekly (minimum of 1500 hours) of fieldwork under supervision of a licensed psychologist. Setting must be approved by CCSP faculty.

CNCSP 279B.title: Internship in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 279B.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and advancement to candidacy.
CNCSP 279B.comments: A three-quarter in progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of CNCSP 279C. May take for 12 units/quarter for  one year, or 6 units/quarter for two years. Total of 36 units required.
CNCSP 279B.description: Advanced fieldwork internship in an approved setting. Twenty to fourty   hours weekly (minimum of 1500 hours) of fieldwork under supervision of a licensed psychologist. Setting must be approved by CCSP faculty.

CNCSP 279C.title: Internship in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 279C.prereq_description: Consent of instructor and advancement to candidacy.
CNCSP 279C.comments: A three-quarter in progress sequence course with grades for all quarters issued upon completion of CNCSP 279C. May take for 12 units/quarter for  one year, or 6 units/quarter for two years. Total of 36 units required.
CNCSP 279C.description: Advanced fieldwork internship in an approved setting. Twenty to fourty   hours weekly (minimum of 1500 hours) of fieldwork undersupervision of a  licensed psychologist. Setting must be approved by CCSP faculty.

CNCSP 290.title: Seminar in Professional Psychology
CNCSP 290.description: Consideration of emerging topics in counseling, clinical, and/or school  psychology. Course content may vary.

CNCSP 291A.title: Human Sexuality for Applied Psychologists
CNCSP 291A.prereq_description: Consent of instructor; must be enrolled in the Counseling/Clinical/School  Psychology Program.
CNCSP 291A.description: Introduces graduate students in applied psychology to physiological and  socio-cultural variables associated with sexual identity, sexual behavior, and sexual functioning.

CNCSP 291B.title: Substance Related Disorders and Other Addictive Behaviors
CNCSP 291B.description: Course addresses causes, prevention, and treatment of drug and alcohol abuse. Designed to meet the requirements for licensure as a psychologist in the State of California.

CNCSP 291C.title: Family Violence
CNCSP 291C.description: Course covers theories relating to the reasons for child abuse and   domestic violence as well as theories and research on family violence and  its treatment.

CNCSP 292.title: Resiliency, Strengths, and Youth Development
CNCSP 292.description: An in-depth review of research literature related to risk and resiliency concepts based on research from fields of developmental psychopathology, developmental delay, school drop-out, and substance abuse prevention.

CNCSP 293.title: Pedagogy in Applied Psychology
CNCSP 293.description: Preparation in teaching psychological concepts and skills in     college-level courses.  The content includes course development,   lectures, cooperative learning, grading, teaching to diverse audiences,  and ethics.  Students will gain teaching experience as group leaders for sections of CNCSP 101.

CNCSP 294.title: Sex, Gender, and Related Constructs in Applied Psychology
CNCSP 294.description: Introduces students to psychological research, theory, and practice related to sex, gender, sexual orientation, gender identity/expression, and sexuality.

CNCSP 596.title: Directed Reading and Research
CNCSP 596.description: Individual tutorial in doctoral and masters' degree subprogram special   fields.

CNCSP 597.title: Individual Study for Comprehensive Examinations
CNCSP 597.description: Preparation for master's or Ph.D. comprehensive examinations.

CNCSP 599.title: Ph.D. Dissertation Preparation
CNCSP 599.description: Supervised research and writing of dissertation in doctoral degree.
